pr_title: Flink: Integrate Iceberg catalog to Flink catalog

timeline.bodyText: We would normally use Preconditions.checkArgument in this case.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Nit: we like to add empty lines after control flow blocks (between the last } and this if).
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Why is this recursive? It seems unnecessary.
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: You are right, asNamespaceCatalog.listNamespaces(Namespace.of(baseNamespace)) is enough.
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.bodyText: Minor: We prefer using the factory methods in Maps instead of specific class names.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: This doesn't seem to handle the default database. What is the correct behavior when the catalog doesn't support namespaces, but this is called for the default database?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Yes, we need handle default database, the correct behavior when the catalog doesn't support namespaces should throw an exception to tell users that the default database can not be altered.
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.bodyText: Passing an empty string is suspicious. Should that be null or omitted to let the impl default?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: I'll modify it to null.
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.bodyText:
Can we add partitioning to the Flink DDL parser instead? That seems like a more appropriate place for it.
Otherwise, I'd recommend just using the PartitionSpecParser.fromJson method.
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText:
I prefer that adding partitioning to the Flink DDL parser. I'll modify the comments.
Using PartitionSpecParser.fromJson looks very difficult to use.
replies.author: JingsongLi

replies.bodyText: After some discussions with Flink developers, we can map Iceberg Partition Transform to Flink Computed Column and Partition. We can support it in future.
replies.author: JingsongLi

replies.bodyText:
PartitionSpecParser.fromJson is how we serialize partition specs internally. It isn't great to expose it directly to users, but would at least make it possible to configure partitioning. If you have a different approach, that is much better!
How would the computed column and partition approach work?
replies.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText:
A rough idea, Flink support computed column: https://ci.apache.org/projects/flink/flink-docs-master/dev/table/sql/create.html#create-table
Flink DDL CREATE TABLE T (pk INT, ... dt STRING, year AS YEAR(dt), month AS MONTH(dt), d AS DAY(dt)) PARTITIONED BY(year, month, d) should be same to Spark DDL CREATE TABLE T (pk INT, ... dt STRING) PARTITIONED BY(YEAR(dt), MONTH(dt), DAY(dt)).
The computed columns are not stored in the real data, they are just virtual columns, which means we can map they to iceberg partition transforms of iceberg table in iceberg Flink Catalog.
replies.author: JingsongLi

replies.bodyText:
Good idea, but there are a couple of things to watch out for:

Where possible, we avoid exposing the actual partition values, in order to maintain a separation between logical queries and physical layout. That way, the physical layout can change, but the logical queries will continue to work. In this case, we would need to make sure that the computed columns are tracked separately so that we don't drop the day column when the table gets converted to partitioning by hour.
Year, month, and day are functions with concrete behavior for Flink SQL, and Iceberg's partitioning may not align with that behavior. So we probably would not want to supply the data for those columns using Iceberg partition values. Instead, I think we should derive them from the dt field.
replies.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText:
Good points.
For Flink SQL, computed columns are virtual columns, the source and sink can just ignore them, the source just produces columns without computed columns, the Flink core will generate computed columns for input records. For sink, Flink core just give the records without computed columns to connector sink.

I see, you mean https://iceberg.apache.org/evolution/#partition-evolution , the computed columns should be calculated by Flink core, iceberg should just deal with its physical logical.
There are three types of function: 1.hour,day,month,year are the same as Flink's functions. 2. For truncate, Flink also supports this function, but not support truncate with input type string and bytes, iceberg can provides catalog function (Catalog.getFunction), users can use iceberg_catalog.truncate to create computed column. 3. For bucket, Flink not support this function, so iceberg can provides catalog functions, users can directly use it.
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Got it.
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.bodyText: This should also be labelled (Hadoop catalog only) because the Hive catalog supports only database.
timeline.author: rdblue

    • + *

    • + *

    • + *

timeline.bodyText: Can you be more specific about this? What is a case where information is lost?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: If I understand correctly, this is lossy because Iceberg doesn't represent some types that Flink supports, like CHAR(N). Is that right?
replies.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Yes
replies.author: JingsongLi

replies.bodyText:
Iceberg to Flink: will loss UUID.
Flink to Iceberg: will loss precisions.
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.bodyText: Char? Wouldn't this be fixed-length binary?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText:
I thought UUID should be a Char with 36 precision because:

In Spark, UUID function returns StringType.
In Flink, UUID function returns CharType with 36 precision.

But you are right, in Orc and Parquet, UUID just be treated as a fixed-length binary.
replies.author: JingsongLi

replies.bodyText: I think either CHAR(36) or VARBINARY(16) would work, but not CHAR(16).
replies.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: I choose fixed-length binary(16).
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.bodyText: Won't this close the catalog after every test method?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText:
Yes, every test method will create a new catalog too.
But it seems we can reuse them by catalog name.
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.bodyText: This sounds like a bug in the Hadoop catalog. Can we fix it instead of ignoring this test case?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: I'll modify in this PR. Tell me if I need create a new PR for fixing hadoop catalog.
replies.author: JingsongLi

replies.bodyText: I think it would be better to fix the Hadoop catalog in a separate PR and leave this one with the Assume until it is merged.
replies.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: I'll create it.
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.bodyText: It isn't clear from this name that this is for a database. How about renaming it to flinkDatabase?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Why does this require assertThrowsCause? Is it wrapped in a generic SQL failure exception?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Yes, in Flink, will wrap an exception like: throw new ValidationException("Could not execute DROP DATABASE", e);, in the top exception, there is no the message that we want to check.
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: In Flink 1.10, not support DDL SHOW TABLES. It is supported in 1.11.
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.bodyText: What is TEMPORARY_FOLDER? I don't see it elsewhere in this PR.
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: TEMPORARY_FOLDER is from Flink test base class AbstractTestBase.
replies.author: JingsongLi

timeline.bodyText: Do we need a test to validate that the CREATE DATABASE statement fails for Hadoop?
timeline.author: rdblue
